item.title: [C++] Challenge: Make a call to a non-public member function
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

Davidi2:

The solution is to make fields public that you need to be public, rather than use retarded design.

I don’t think you understood the purpose of the challenge. Of course this is not a practical task, you would not write such code in production. The challenge was made to see how well people know language details and it’s corner cases. Clearly, when one is not able to complete this challenge, then that person is not aware of function pointers to member functions. As you can see this is a problem solving challenge, it forces you to think of a language feature to solve an uncommon problem. People who are unable to solve (new) problems are a failure.

Read full topic

item.source: [C++] Challenge: Make a call to a non-public member function

item.title: [C++] Challenge: Make a call to a non-public member function
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

I’m quite disappointed that none of you could come up with a solution.

The solution here is to create a derived class and use it to get a function pointer to A::function, then that pointer can be used to make a direct call to a.function().

#include <iostream>

class A
{
public:
	A(unsigned int i)
	{
		m_i = i;
	}

	~A(void)
	{

	}

protected:
	void function(void)
	{
		std::cout << "A " << m_i << std::endl;
	}

private:
	unsigned int m_i;
};

class B : public A
{
public:
	B(void) : A(0)
	{

	}

	~B(void)
	{

	}

	static void (A::* address(void)) (void)
	{
		return &B::function;
	}
};

int main(void)
{
	A a(200);
	void (A::* pFunction) (void) = B::address();
	(a.*pFunction)(); //Make a call to a.function().

	std::cin.sync();
	std::cin.get();
	return 0;
}

Read full topic

item.title: [C++] Challenge: Make a call to a non-public member function
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

Pwnd:

Do your own homework

You’re a moron. This is a challenge for other people on this forum, made by me.

[quote=“sspoke, post:3, topic:425541”]You can write up a class that is derived from the class A and be able to call that protected function.

then do

might work[/quote]
Since you did not provide a full code sample, I’m only going to assume what you wanted to do. If you derive from that class, the protected function is still protected, you can’t call it directly. Also, force-casting an object of a base class into an object of a derived class is not a good idea, that’s undefined behaviour.

I’ll post a solution soon if none of you can think of one.

Read full topic

item.source: [C++] Challenge: Make a call to a non-public member function

item.title: [C++] Challenge: Make a call to a non-public member function
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

These forums are quite boring, so here’s a challenge that I came up with a while ago. I posted it on a different forum a long time ago, so try to do it without using google.

#include <iostream>

class A
{
public:
	A(unsigned int i)
	{
		m_i = i;
	}

	~A(void)
	{

	}

protected:
	void function(void)
	{
		std::cout << "A " << m_i << std::endl;
	}

private:
	unsigned int m_i;
};

int main(void)
{
	A a(200);	
	//Make a call to a.function().

	std::cin.sync();
	std::cin.get();
	return 0;
}

You will have to make a successful function call to a.function().

Rules:

  1. Do not modify class A.
  2. The function call must be made directly from the main function.
  3. Write only standard C++ code.
  4. No inline asm.

I’ll be posting my solution later, let’s see if any of you can come up with one.

Read full topic
